hook.text: A photorealistic portrait. A Pixar-style character. A simple emoji face. A geometric abstraction. All depict 'a person' â€” but each sits at a different point on the stylization spectrum, from literal to abstract.

buildup.text: The spectrum: photorealism â†’ classical realism â†’ stylized realism â†’ cartoon â†’ simplified â†’ geometric â†’ abstract â†’ icon/symbol. Each level removes detail and adds simplification. Each level communicates differently.

discovery.text: Scott McCloud's insight: the more abstract a face, the more people project themselves onto it. A detailed realistic face is 'that specific person.' A simple smiley face is 'anyone â€” including me.' Abstraction increases universality.

twist.text: Consistency within your chosen level matters more than the level itself. Mixing photorealistic hands with cartoon faces breaks the illusion. Commit to a level of stylization and apply it consistently to every element.

climax.text: Draw the same face at 5 points on the spectrum: photorealistic, stylized (like Pixar), cartoony, simplified (like a logo), and iconic (smiley face). Notice how each level communicates differently and evokes different emotional responses.

punchline.text: There's no 'correct' point on the spectrum. The right level of stylization serves the message â€” and becomes your style.

quiz.question: According to Scott McCloud, why do more abstract/simplified faces feel more universal?
options: Viewers project themselves onto simpler faces because they could represent anyone
